title: Beat Procrastination and Write Research Papers Faster
text:
Want to beat procrastination and draft faster?
Here are some of the most effective tips I‚Äôve gathered that truly work.



Stop editing as you write! Your first draft is about getting ideas down, not grammar or polish.

Editing too early wastes time and fuels procrastination.

Save grammar, clarity, and formatting for later rounds.

‚úÖ Perfectionism = procrastination. A rough draft builds clarity and momentum.




Here‚Äôs a plan that simplifies writing and saves time:

Structure first: Outline using your target journal‚Äôs template.

Write key sections first (Methods, Results).

Intro/Abstract last: they‚Äôll be sharper once your content is final.

Draft fast: Aim for 1 section/day. Quarto‚Äôs dynamic formatting/code tools remove friction.

Revise after drafting: Polishing a full draft is faster and more motivating than fixing fragments.






Perfectionism slows you down ‚Äî draft first, polish later.

Writing a rough Version 0 clears mental blocks and creates momentum.

Quarto Manuscript helps you stay focused on ideas, not formatting.


üí° Want to try these methods? Start with your next project: create a Quarto outline, commit to Version 0, and watch how much faster your draft grows.

Thanks for stopping by! Hope you found something useful :)

title: From RStudio to Published Paper: Writing Manuscripts with Quarto
text:
Most researchers today already use R and RStudio for their data analysis. We run models, generate tables, and produce figures, all within the same environment.
But when it comes to writing the actual manuscript, we often switch tools: exporting results to Word, formatting references in citation managers, or handing over LaTeX code to journals. This adds friction, duplication, and errors.
The question is: why leave RStudio when you can write your manuscript there too?
With Quarto, you can now write your entire paper in RStudio, combining:

Your text and manuscript structure.

Your code chunks (R, Python, Julia, etc).

Figures and tables, perfectly placed and automatically updated.

References and citations handled automatically.

Multiple output formats (Word, PDF, HTML) in one click.

It‚Äôs a single, reproducible workflow: from data to manuscript.

title: From RStudio to Published Paper: Writing Manuscripts with Quarto
section: Getting Started with Quarto in RStudio
text:
Getting Started with Quarto in RStudio
You don‚Äôt need a new tool. Quarto comes as part of RStudio (Posit IDE).
To create a manuscript:

In RStudio, go to: File ‚Üí New Project.

Select New Directory ‚Üí Quarto Manuscript.

Give your project a name (e.g., my-paper) and choose where to save it.

RStudio will create a dedicated project folder containing all the necessary Quarto files for your manuscript.

Your project will have:
my-paper/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ index.qmd        # Main manuscript file
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ references.bib   # Bibliography file
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ _quarto.yml      # Project settings
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ figures/         # Store your figures here

title: From RStudio to Published Paper: Writing Manuscripts with Quarto
text:
Writing Your Manuscript
The index.qmd file is where you write your paper. It looks like this:
---
title: "My Research Paper"
author: "Your Name"
date: "2025-09-20"
format:
  pdf: default
  docx: default
  html: default
bibliography: references.bib
---

# Abstract

A short summary of your work.

# Introduction

Why this research matters...

# Methods


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# Example R code included in the paper
library(ggplot2)
ggplot(mtcars, aes(wt, mpg)) + geom_point()
```
:::


# Results

Here is where the code-generated figure will appear.

# Discussion

Interpret your findings.

# References
üëâ Notice how code and narrative are written side by side. When you render the manuscript, the figure produced by ggplot2 is automatically inserted, formatted, and captioned.

title: From RStudio to Published Paper: Writing Manuscripts with Quarto
text:
Adding References
Quarto uses a references.bib file (BibTeX format). Example entry:
@article{smith2020,
  title={Data Science in Healthcare},
  author={Smith, John and Doe, Jane},
  journal={Journal of Health Analytics},
  year={2020},
  volume={12},
  number={3},
  pages={123-135}
}
In your manuscript, cite it like this:
Research in this field is expanding rapidly [@smith2020].
At the end, Quarto automatically generates the bibliography.
Want APA style? Add this to the YAML:
csl: apa.csl
(Download styles from Zotero‚Äôs style repository).

title: From RStudio to Published Paper: Writing Manuscripts with Quarto
text:
Rendering Your Paper
In RStudio, click the Render button (or run quarto render in the terminal).
This generates:

Word document (index.docx) ‚Äî ready to share with supervisors or collaborators.

PDF (index.pdf) ‚Äî beautifully typeset.

HTML (index.html) ‚Äî great for online publishing or lab websites.

All from the same source file.
